expanded_description: Before diving into advanced statistics, we need a rock-solid foundation: how do we summarize data with just a few numbers? Central tendency tells us where data clusters — the 'typical' value. Dispersion tells us how spread out the data is. Master these, and every future statistics concept will click into place.

core_concept.principle: Any dataset can be described by answering two questions: (1) Where is the center? (2) How spread out is the data?
core_concept.explanation: Imagine your class took a test. You might ask: 'What was the average score?' (center) and 'Were most scores close together, or all over the place?' (spread). Measures of central tendency — mean, median, and mode — answer the first question. Measures of dispersion — range, variance, standard deviation, and IQR — answer the second. You need BOTH to truly understand a dataset. A mean of 75 means something very different if scores ranged from 74–76 versus 20–100.

sections.introduction: The mean is what most people think of when they hear 'average.' You've been calculating means since middle school — add everything up and divide by how many there are. In statistics, we'll use precise notation and think more carefully about when the mean is the right tool to use.

key_concept.definition: The mean is the sum of all values divided by the number of values. It represents the 'balance point' of a dataset — if each value were a weight on a number line, the mean is where it would balance perfectly.
key_concept.context: We use different symbols depending on whether we have a sample (a subset of a population) or the entire population. Sample mean: $\bar{x}$ (read 'x-bar'). Population mean: $\mu$ (the Greek letter 'mu'). In Algebra 2 statistics, we almost always work with samples.

classifications.value: Best when: data is roughly symmetric, no extreme outliers, and you want to use all the information in the dataset
characteristics: Formula: $\bar{x} = (x_1 + x_2 + ... + x_n) / n$, or more compactly: $\bar{x} = \sum x / n$
The symbol $\sum$ (sigma) means 'sum of' — add up all the $x$ values
$n$ = the number of values in the dataset
Uses EVERY value in the calculation — its strength and its weakness
The mean is 'sensitive' to outliers — one extreme value can dramatically shift it
The mean may not be an actual value in your dataset (e.g., mean of 2, 3, 4 is 3, but mean of 2, 3, 5 is 3.33...)
classifications.behavior: Add all values together. Divide by the count. That's it. The challenge is interpreting what you get: a mean of 80 on a test sounds great until you realize 28 students scored 82+ and 2 students scored 4 (dragging the mean down). Always ask: is the mean being distorted by extreme values?

examples.explanation: 7 students scored: 72, 85, 90, 88, 95, 78, 82 on a quiz. Step 1 — Add: 72+85+90+88+95+78+82 = 590. Step 2 — Divide by $n=7$: $590/7 \approx 84.3$. The mean quiz score is about 84.3 points.

You can multiply repeated values instead of listing them: Data: 10, 10, 10, 20, 20, 30. Rather than 10+10+10+20+20+30=100, notice three 10s, two 20s, one 30: $3(10)+2(20)+1(30) = 30+40+30 = 100$. Mean = $100/6 \approx 16.7$.

examples.process: The Outlier Problem — Why Mean Can Mislead
examples.explanation: Scenario: 5 friends compare weekly allowances: \$20, \$25, \$18, \$22, \$500. Mean = $(20+25+18+22+500)/5 = 585/5 = \$117$. Does \$117 represent a 'typical' allowance here? No — four of the five friends get \$18–\$25. One friend's \$500 obliterated the average. This is why we need the median.

You scored 82, 79, and 91 on three tests. What score do you need on the 4th test to have a mean of 85? Set up: $(82+79+91+x)/4 = 85$. Multiply both sides by 4: $252+x = 340$. $x = 88$. You need an 88 on the 4th test.

sections.introduction: The median literally means 'the middle.' It's the value that splits an ordered dataset exactly in half — 50% of the data falls below it, 50% above it. Unlike the mean, the median doesn't use the actual values of the data points, just their order. This makes it powerful when extreme values are present.

key_concept.definition: The median is the middle value of an ordered dataset. To find it, you MUST sort the data first. If there are two middle values (even number of data points), the median is their mean.
key_concept.context: The median is called a 'resistant' measure because outliers don't affect it. The median of {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} is 3. The median of {1, 2, 3, 4, 1000} is STILL 3 — that 1000 doesn't move the middle. This is why median household income is reported instead of mean household income.

classifications.value: Best when: data is skewed (pulled in one direction), outliers are present, or you're measuring income, prices, reaction times, or other quantities where extremes are common
characteristics: ALWAYS sort the data from least to greatest BEFORE finding the median
For ODD $n$: Median = the value at position $(n+1)/2$
For EVEN $n$: Median = mean of the values at positions $n/2$ and $(n/2)+1$
Resistant to outliers — extreme values don't change it
Does not use the actual magnitude of values, only their order
Splits the data exactly in half: 50th percentile
classifications.behavior: Step 1: Sort all values smallest to largest. Step 2: Count how many values you have ($n$). Step 3: If $n$ is odd, the median is literally the middle number. If $n$ is even, average the two middle numbers. A quick check — for $n$ values, the middle is at position $(n+1)/2$. For $n=7$, that's position 4. For $n=8$, positions 4 and 5 need to be averaged.

examples.explanation: Data (already sorted): 14, 21, 27, 35, 42, 58, 63. $n = 7$ (odd). Middle position = $(7+1)/2 = 4$th value. Count to position 4: 14, 21, 27, [35], 42, 58, 63. Median = 35. Three values below it, three above it — perfect split.

Data (already sorted): 8, 13, 17, 24, 31, 45. $n = 6$ (even). The two middle positions are $6/2 = 3$rd and 4th. Those values are 17 and 24. Median = $(17+24)/2 = 41/2 = 20.5$. Note: 20.5 is NOT in the dataset — that's perfectly fine.

Common mistake: Data is given as 42, 17, 8, 31, 24, 13. A student might grab the middle values as 8 and 31 (positions 3 and 4 as given). WRONG. Sort first: 8, 13, 17, 24, 31, 42. Now positions 3 and 4 are 17 and 24. Median = 20.5. Always sort!

8 employees' salaries: \$28k, \$31k, \$33k, \$35k, \$38k, \$41k, \$44k, \$200k. Mean = $(28+31+33+35+38+41+44+200)/8 = 450/8 = \$56,250$. Median: $n=8$ (even), average positions 4 & 5 = $(\$35k+\$38k)/2 = \$36,500$. The CEO makes \$200k; the other 7 make \$28k–\$44k. The median (\$36,500) represents a typical worker. The mean (\$56,250) does not.

sections.introduction: The mode is the simplest measure of central tendency — it's just whatever value shows up most often. It's the only measure that works with categorical (non-numerical) data, making it uniquely useful in certain situations. However, it can be misleading or meaningless if used incorrectly.

key_concept.definition: The mode is the value (or values) that appear most frequently in a dataset. A dataset can be unimodal (one mode), bimodal (two modes), multimodal (multiple modes), or have no mode at all.
key_concept.context: The mode answers a different question than mean or median — not 'what's typical on a number scale' but 'what's most popular or most common.' A shoe store asks: 'What size sells most?' That's a mode question. The mean shoe size wouldn't help them stock inventory.

classifications.value: Best when: identifying the most popular/common item, working with categorical data, or spotting clusters in data
characteristics: No calculation needed — just count frequencies
Works with categorical data (colors, names, types) — mean and median don't
A dataset can have NO mode (all values unique), ONE mode (unimodal), or MULTIPLE modes (bimodal, multimodal)
The mode is not necessarily near the center of the data
Multiple modes can hint at distinct subgroups in your data
Least commonly used measure for continuous numerical data
classifications.behavior: List all values and count how many times each appears. The value(s) with the highest count are the mode(s). If all values appear the same number of times, there is no mode. If two values tie for most frequent, both are modes — do not average them.

examples.explanation: Favorite colors in a class: Red, Blue, Blue, Green, Blue, Red, Yellow, Blue. Tally: Red=2, Blue=4, Green=1, Yellow=1. Mode = Blue. This is categorical data — you couldn't find a mean or median of colors.

Quiz scores: 70, 70, 75, 80, 85, 85, 90. Tally: 70 appears twice, 85 appears twice, all others once. Mode = 70 AND 85. A bimodal distribution often means two distinct groups — perhaps students who studied and students who didn't.
Ages: 14, 15, 16, 17, 18. Every value appears exactly once. There is no mode. Don't say 'the mode is 0' or make one up — just say there is no mode.

A store records shoe sizes sold in one day: 7, 8, 8, 9, 9, 9, 10, 10, 10, 10, 11, 11, 12. Tally: size 10 appears 4 times (most). Mode = 10. The store should order more size 10s — this is a mode question, not a mean question.

sections.section_title: Measures of Dispersion — Spread and Variability
sections.introduction: Here's a critical insight: two datasets can have identical means, medians, and modes — yet look completely different. Consider two classes that both averaged 80 on a test. In Class A, every student scored between 78 and 82. In Class B, half scored 60 and half scored 100. The center is the same, but the spread is completely different. Measures of dispersion capture this difference.

key_concept.definition: Dispersion (also called spread or variability) measures how much the values in a dataset differ from each other and from the center. A small dispersion means data points are clustered tightly; a large dispersion means they are scattered widely.
key_concept.context: Think of it this way: if someone says 'the average temperature in this city in June is 75°F,' you'd want to know if it's 75°F every single day (low dispersion — very predictable) or if some days are 55°F and others 95°F (high dispersion — pack layers AND sunscreen). Same average, very different experience.

classifications.value: Use for a quick, rough estimate of spread — easy to calculate but easily distorted by outliers
characteristics: Formula: $\text{Range} = \text{Maximum value} - \text{Minimum value}$
Only uses the two most extreme values; ignores everything in between
Very easy to calculate
Highly sensitive to outliers — one extreme value creates a misleadingly large range
A starting point, not a complete picture of spread
classifications.behavior: Find the largest value in your dataset. Find the smallest. Subtract. The result tells you the total span of the data — but nothing about how values are distributed within that span.

examples.explanation: Test scores: 62, 75, 80, 85, 88, 92, 98. Max = 98, Min = 62. Range = $98 - 62 = 36$. Scores span a 36-point window.

Scores: 78, 80, 82, 84, 86, 12. Range = $86 - 12 = 74$. But remove that 12 and range = $86 - 78 = 8$! That one outlier makes the range 74 instead of 8 — wildly misleading. This is why range alone is not enough.

classifications.value: A conceptual building block — understanding deviation is essential before learning variance and standard deviation
characteristics: Deviation = $x - \bar{x}$ (individual value minus the mean)
A positive deviation means the value is ABOVE the mean
A negative deviation means the value is BELOW the mean
A deviation of 0 means the value equals the mean
The sum of all deviations always equals zero — positives and negatives cancel out
This is why we can't just average the deviations — we need to square them first
classifications.behavior: For each data point, ask: how far is it from the mean, and in which direction? The deviation tells you. But if you try to average all deviations to measure spread, they always sum to zero because the mean is the balance point. We fix this by squaring the deviations.

examples.explanation: Data: 3, 5, 7. Mean = $(3+5+7)/3 = 5$. Deviations: $(3-5)=-2$, $(5-5)=0$, $(7-5)=+2$. Sum of deviations = $-2+0+2 = 0$. Always zero! So we can't use deviations directly — we must square them.

Squaring deviations does two things: (1) Makes all values positive, so they don't cancel. (2) Penalizes larger deviations more — a deviation of 6 gets squared to 36, while a deviation of 2 gets squared to just 4. This reflects that points far from the mean represent more variability.

classifications.value: An intermediate measure — essential for calculating standard deviation, but rarely interpreted directly because its units are squared
characteristics: Sample variance formula: $s^2 = \frac{\sum (x - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1}$
Population variance formula: $\sigma^2 = \frac{\sum (x - \mu)^2}{N}$
We use $(n-1)$ for samples, not $n$ — this is called 'Bessel's correction' and makes our estimate more accurate
Variance is always $\ge 0$; it equals 0 only if all values are identical
Units are SQUARED: if data is in dollars, variance is in dollars$^2$ — which is hard to interpret
Larger variance = more spread out data
classifications.behavior: Step 1: Find the mean. Step 2: Subtract the mean from each value to get deviations. Step 3: Square each deviation. Step 4: Add up all squared deviations. Step 5: Divide by $(n-1)$ for a sample. The result is variance. You rarely stop here — you take the square root to get standard deviation.

examples.explanation: When we have a sample, we're using $\bar{x}$ (our sample mean) as a stand-in for the true population mean $\mu$. This introduces a slight error. Dividing by $n-1$ instead of $n$ compensates for that error, giving us a better estimate. With a full population, use $N$. For this course: samples → $(n-1)$, populations → $N$.

classifications.value: The most important and widely used measure of spread — tells you, in the original units, how far a typical value falls from the mean
characteristics: Sample: $s = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (x - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1}}$
Population: $\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (x - \mu)^2}{N}}$
Standard deviation is simply the square root of variance
Taking the square root returns us to the original units of measurement
Always non-negative; equals 0 only if all values are identical
Sensitive to outliers (like the mean) — one extreme value increases $s$ significantly
Roughly: about 68% of data falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean (we'll formalize this in Section 10.2)
classifications.behavior: Take every step of variance, then take the square root at the end. The result tells you the 'typical distance' from the mean. If $s = 5$ points on a test, most scores are within 5 points of the mean in either direction. A small $s$ means data is tightly packed; a large $s$ means data is widely spread.

examples.explanation: From the variance example: data 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 had variance $s^2 = 10$. Standard deviation $s = \sqrt{10} \approx 3.16$. So on average, each value is about 3.16 units away from the mean of 6. Check: 2 is 4 away, 4 is 2 away, 6 is 0 away, 8 is 2 away, 10 is 4 away. Average distance ≈ 2.4 (not exactly 3.16 because of squaring, but the idea holds).

Class A test: mean = 80, $s = 2$. Class B test: mean = 80, $s = 15$. Both averages are identical. Class A: most students scored between 78–82 (very consistent). Class B: scores are scattered, many between 65–95 (wildly inconsistent). Standard deviation reveals what the mean hides.

Dataset 1: {5, 5, 5, 5, 5}. Mean = 5, $s = 0$. Every value IS the mean — zero spread. Dataset 2: {1, 3, 5, 7, 9}. Mean = 5, $s \approx 3.16$. Values vary from the mean. Dataset 3: {$-10$, 0, 5, 10, 30}. Mean = 7, $s \approx 14.6$. Wide spread. As spread increases, $s$ increases.

classifications.value: Use when data is skewed or has outliers — a resistant measure of spread that works well alongside the median
characteristics: $Q_1$ (first quartile) = median of the lower half of the data = 25th percentile
$Q_3$ (third quartile) = median of the upper half of the data = 75th percentile
IQR represents the spread of the MIDDLE 50% of data
Resistant to outliers — extreme values don't affect $Q_1$ or $Q_3$
Used to detect outliers: any value below $Q_1 - 1.5(\text{IQR})$ or above $Q_3 + 1.5(\text{IQR})$ is considered an outlier
Pairs naturally with the median, just as standard deviation pairs with the mean
classifications.behavior: Step 1: Sort data. Step 2: Find the median — this splits the data into a lower half and upper half. Step 3: Find $Q_1$ = median of the lower half. Step 4: Find $Q_3$ = median of the upper half. Step 5: IQR = $Q_3 - Q_1$. The IQR tells you how spread out the 'middle crowd' is, ignoring the extreme high and low values.

examples.explanation: Data (sorted): 3, 7, 8, 12, 15, 18, 22, 26, 31. $n = 9$. Median = 5th value = 15. Lower half (below median): 3, 7, 8, 12. $Q_1$ = median of lower half = $(7+8)/2 = 7.5$. Upper half (above median): 18, 22, 26, 31. $Q_3$ = median of upper half = $(22+26)/2 = 24$. IQR = $24 - 7.5 = 16.5$.

Data: 12, 15, 17, 19, 21, 23, 25, 27, 85. $Q_1 = 16$, $Q_3 = 25$, IQR = 9. Lower fence = $Q_1 - 1.5(\text{IQR}) = 16 - 13.5 = 2.5$. Upper fence = $Q_3 + 1.5(\text{IQR}) = 25 + 13.5 = 38.5$. The value 85 $>$ 38.5, so 85 is an outlier. All other values fall between 2.5 and 38.5, so they are not outliers.

Same dataset: 12, 15, 17, 19, 21, 23, 25, 27, 85. Range = $85 - 12 = 73$. IQR = 9. The range says the data spans 73 units. The IQR says the middle 50% spans only 9 units. The outlier (85) inflates the range enormously. IQR gives a clearer picture of where most data lives.

sections.introduction: Students often ask: 'Do I calculate all of them every time?' In practice, you choose based on the shape of your data and the presence of outliers. Here's the framework you'll use throughout this course and beyond.

key_concept.definition: The choice of measure depends on whether the data is symmetric or skewed, and whether outliers are present. Using the wrong measure can make your summary statistics misleading.
key_concept.context: Rule of thumb: Symmetric data with no outliers → use mean and standard deviation. Skewed data or data with outliers → use median and IQR. When in doubt, report both and note any outliers.

categories.description: Data forms a roughly balanced, bell-shaped pattern. The mean and median will be close or equal. No extreme values pulling the distribution in one direction.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Use mean as the measure of center and standard deviation as the measure of spread. These measures use the actual value of every data point, making them more statistically powerful. They're also the foundation of the normal distribution and z-scores (Sections 10.2–10.3).

examples.explanation: Heights cluster around 5'7\" with roughly equal numbers taller and shorter. Mean ≈ Median ≈ 5'7\". Report: mean = 67 inches, standard deviation = 2.5 inches.

examples.process: IQ scores in a large population
examples.explanation: IQ is designed to be symmetric. Most people score near 100, with equal numbers above and below. Mean ≈ Median = 100. Standard deviation = 15. Mean and s.d. are the right measures here.

categories.description: Data is pulled toward one extreme. There may be a long tail on one side. The mean is dragged toward the tail; the median stays near the bulk of the data. Using the mean here gives a misleading picture.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Use median as the measure of center and IQR as the measure of spread. These 'resistant' measures are not influenced by the extreme values in the tail. Real-world data — incomes, house prices, wait times, response times — is frequently right-skewed (long tail on the right) because values can't go below zero but can be extremely high.

examples.explanation: Most households earn \$40k–\$100k, but a few earn millions, creating a long right tail. Mean income is pulled high by the wealthy few. Median income (\$68,703 per U.S. Census data) better represents a typical household. Report: median and IQR.

Most houses cost \$200k–\$350k, but one historic estate sells for \$2 million. Mean price: ~\$420k. Median price: ~\$275k. A buyer looking for a typical home should care about the median, not the mean.

examples.process: Test Scores with One Very Low Score
examples.explanation: 10 students: 88, 91, 85, 90, 87, 93, 82, 89, 86, 14. The student who scored 14 was absent for most of the unit. Mean ≈ 80.5, Median = 87.5. The median tells us where the 'real' class performed. Report the outlier separately.

worked_examples.title: Full Statistical Summary — From Scratch
worked_examples.problem: A sample of 11 students reported the number of hours they studied for a final exam: 8, 3, 5, 7, 2, 6, 5, 9, 5, 4, 1. Find the mean, median, mode, range, variance, standard deviation, $Q_1$, $Q_3$, and IQR. Then decide which measures best summarize this data.

step_by_step.explanation: Always start here — you need sorted data for median, quartiles, and range.
Add all values, divide by $n = 11$.
$n = 11$ (odd). Middle position = $(11+1)/2 = 6$th value.
Find the most frequently occurring value.
step_by_step.calculation: The value 5 appears 3 times (positions 5, 6, 7). All others appear once. Mode = 5 hours.

step_by_step.explanation: Maximum minus minimum.
Find each deviation from the mean $(x - \bar{x})$, square it, sum them up, divide by $n-1 = 10$.
Take the square root of variance.
step_by_step.calculation: $s = \sqrt{6} \approx 2.45$ hours. So the typical student's hours deviate from the mean of 5 by about 2.45 hours.

step_by_step.explanation: Split the sorted data at the median (6th value = 5). Lower half: positions 1–5. Upper half: positions 7–11.
step_by_step.calculation: Lower half: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. $Q_1$ = median = 3. Upper half: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. $Q_3$ = median = 7.
IQR = $7 - 3 = 4$ hours. The middle 50% of students studied within a 4-hour window.

step_by_step.explanation: Use the IQR fence rule.
step_by_step.calculation: Lower fence = $Q_1 - 1.5(\text{IQR}) = 3 - 6 = -3$. Upper fence = $Q_3 + 1.5(\text{IQR}) = 7 + 6 = 13$. All values fall between $-3$ and 13, so no outliers.

step_by_step.explanation: No outliers, and mean = median = mode = 5 — the distribution appears symmetric. The mean and standard deviation are appropriate here.
step_by_step.calculation: Summary: Mean = 5 hours, Standard deviation $\approx 2.45$ hours. Note: median, mode, and IQR are consistent with these findings.

worked_examples.final_answer: Mean = 5, Median = 5, Mode = 5, Range = 8, $s^2 = 6$, $s \approx 2.45$, $Q_1 = 3$, $Q_3 = 7$, IQR = 4. No outliers detected. Best summary: mean = 5 hours, standard deviation $\approx 2.45$ hours (symmetric data, no outliers).
worked_examples.concept_applied: When mean = median = mode, the distribution is likely symmetric, and all three measures of center give the same answer. Standard deviation is the appropriate measure of spread.

worked_examples.title: Catching a Misleading Mean
worked_examples.problem: A real estate agent claims: 'The average home price on Maple Street is \$312,500 — very affordable!' The 8 home prices on Maple Street are: \$185,000 | \$195,000 | \$202,000 | \$210,000 | \$218,000 | \$225,000 | \$230,000 | \$935,000. Evaluate the agent's claim.

step_by_step.step: Calculate the Mean (Verify the Agent's Claim)
step_by_step.explanation: Add all prices and divide by 8.
step_by_step.calculation: Sum = 185+195+202+210+218+225+230+935 = 2,400 (in thousands). Mean = $2,400/8 = \$300,000$. Close to the agent's \$312,500 — they may have rounded or used slightly different data.

step_by_step.explanation: $n = 8$ (even). Average the 4th and 5th values.
Apply the fence rule using IQR = 29,000.

The mean ($\$300,000$) is pulled dramatically upward by the one mansion ($\$935,000$). Seven of eight homes are priced between \$185,000 and \$230,000. The median ($\$214,000$) represents a typical home on this street.
step_by_step.calculation: Mean = $\$300,000$ (distorted by outlier). Median = $\$214,000$ (represents 7 of 8 homes accurately).

worked_examples.final_answer: The agent's claim is misleading. The mean ($\$300,000$) is distorted by one outlier — a \$935,000 mansion. The median ($\$214,000$) is the appropriate measure of center and paints a very different picture of affordability.
worked_examples.concept_applied: When outliers are present, the mean is pulled toward the extreme value and becomes unrepresentative. Always check for outliers before reporting a mean as the 'typical' value.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Two Datasets with the Same Mean
worked_examples.problem: Two Algebra 2 classes both scored a mean of 78 on the same unit test. Class A scores: 74, 76, 77, 78, 78, 79, 80, 82. Class B scores: 55, 62, 70, 78, 78, 85, 92, 104. Wait — can you score 104 on a 100-point test? Let's say it was extra credit. Compare the classes using standard deviation. Which class performed more consistently?

step_by_step.explanation: Quick check that both datasets have mean 78.
Find each deviation from 78, square it, sum, divide by $n-1=7$, take square root.
Same process for Class B.
Class A has $s \approx 2.45$; Class B has $s \approx 15.9$. Same mean, dramatically different spreads.
step_by_step.calculation: Class A: most scores within $78 \pm 2.45$, so roughly 75.5–80.5. Class B: most scores within $78 \pm 15.9$, so roughly 62–94.

worked_examples.final_answer: Class A: mean = 78, $s \approx 2.45$ (very consistent — all students performed similarly). Class B: mean = 78, $s \approx 15.9$ (highly variable — some students excelled, others struggled significantly). The mean alone is completely inadequate to describe these classes. Standard deviation reveals the true story.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Identical means do NOT mean identical distributions. Standard deviation is essential context for any mean — it reveals whether the mean represents a tight cluster or a scattered spread.

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: These are the errors students most frequently make on tests and in homework. Read carefully — knowing the concept is not enough if you fall into these traps.

key_concept.definition: Statistical errors often come from skipping steps (forgetting to sort), misidentifying the middle value, or confusing when to use each measure.
key_concept.context: Slow down and follow the steps in order. These procedures have no shortcuts.

categories.type: Mistake 1: Forgetting to Sort Before Finding Median or Quartiles
categories.description: The median ONLY makes sense if the data is ordered. If you skip sorting, you will get the wrong answer every time.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Always write 'Step 1: Sort' before finding median, $Q_1$, $Q_3$, IQR, or range. This applies even if the data 'looks mostly sorted' — always verify.

examples.explanation: Data given as: 15, 3, 9, 7, 11. Wrong median: grab middle value as given → 9. Correct: sort first → 3, 7, 9, 11, 15 → Median = 9. Lucky this time, but don't count on it: try 15, 7, 3, 11, 9 → wrong middle would be 3, correct is still 9.

categories.type: Mistake 2: Dividing by $n$ Instead of $n-1$ for Sample Variance
categories.description: For a sample, always divide the sum of squared deviations by $(n-1)$, not $n$. Using $n$ underestimates the true population variance.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Memory trick: 'Samples get the minus one.' If the problem says 'population,' use $N$. If it says 'sample' or doesn't specify, use $n-1$. In this course, assume sample unless told otherwise.

examples.explanation: Data: 4, 8, 12. Mean = 8. Sum of squared deviations = 16+0+16 = 32. With $n=3$: variance = $32/3 \approx 10.67$, $s \approx 3.27$. With $n-1=2$: variance = $32/2 = 16$, $s = 4$. Sample variance $(n-1)$ gives a larger, more accurate estimate of the true spread.

categories.type: Mistake 3: Averaging Two Modes in a Bimodal Dataset
categories.description: If a dataset has two modes, report BOTH — do not average them. The mode is not about calculation, it's about identification.
categories.detailed_mechanism: If values 3 and 7 both appear most frequently, the modes are 3 AND 7. Writing 'mode = 5' (the average) is wrong — 5 may not even appear in the dataset.

examples.explanation: Data: 2, 3, 3, 5, 7, 7, 9. Modes are 3 and 7 — each appears twice. Wrong answer: $(3+7)/2 = 5$ is not the mode. Correct: Mode = 3 and 7.

categories.type: Mistake 4: Using Mean and Standard Deviation When Outliers Are Present
categories.description: When extreme values distort the mean, reporting mean $\pm$ standard deviation gives a misleading picture. Switch to median and IQR.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Check for outliers BEFORE choosing your summary statistics. If outliers exist, report median and IQR. You can note the outlier and mention the mean separately, but make clear it's not representative.

examples.explanation: Salaries: \$30k, \$32k, \$35k, \$38k, \$1,200k. Mean = \$267k. To say 'typical salary is \$267k $\pm$ standard deviation' is wildly misleading. Correct: Median = \$35k, IQR = \$6k — the middle 50% of salaries span \$6k, centered around \$35k.

summary: Measures of central tendency describe where data clusters: the mean (sum $\div$ count) uses every value and works best for symmetric data; the median (middle of sorted data) resists outliers and works best for skewed data; the mode (most frequent value) is the only measure usable with categorical data. Measures of dispersion describe spread: the range (max $-$ min) is quick but sensitive to outliers; variance (average squared deviation from the mean) is the bridge to standard deviation; standard deviation ($\sqrt{\text{variance}}$) tells you how far a typical value sits from the mean in original units; and IQR ($Q_3 - Q_1$) measures the spread of the middle 50% and pairs with the median when outliers are present. The fundamental rule: symmetric data with no outliers $\rightarrow$ use mean and standard deviation; skewed data or outliers present $\rightarrow$ use median and IQR. Always look at your data before choosing — a single extreme value can change which measures are appropriate.
